Question Text: What are some of the features that an SDX enables that today's IXPs cannot support? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Application of different business relationships across different regions of the world (e.g., peering only in a specific geographic region).
b. Application-specific peering
c. Wide-area load balancing using DNS-based redirection
d. On-the-fly redirection to middleboxes
e. Wide-area load balancing using IP packet rewriting
LLM Explanation: An SDX (Software Defined Exchange) enables several features that traditional Internet Exchange Points (IXPs) cannot support, including: a) Applying different business relationships across different regions, allowing peering to be restricted to specific geographic areas. b) Application-specific peering, where peering relationships can be established based on the application or traffic type. d) On-the-fly redirection of traffic to middleboxes for services like security filtering, load balancing, etc. The other options, c) and e), relate to wide-area load balancing techniques that are not specifically enabled by SDX capabilities.
